node.text:
Why do some pine nuts cause a bad taste in your mouth that can last for weeks?

The video sources, transcript, and doctor's notes are available here: https://bit.ly/3u25Cg5

node.text:
The food industry fought tooth and nail to retain partially hydrogenated oils, even though they were killing 50,000 Americans a year. 

The video sources, transcript, and doctor's notes are available here: https://bit.ly/2SXD0Hx

node.text:
There is a food that offers the best of both worlds—significantly improving our ability to detox carcinogens like diesel fumes and decreasing inflammation in our airways—all while improving our respiratory defenses against infections. 

The video sources, transcript, and doctor's notes are available here: https://bit.ly/3j2Is6p

node.text:
Exercise may help prevent age-related immune decline. Sedentary women in their seventies, for example, may have a 50 percent chance of getting an upper respiratory illness during the fall season every year, but their risk drops down to 20 percent when they walk just half an hour a day.⁠
⁠
As we go from inactive to active, our infection risk declines, but, if we overtrain as hardcore athletes often do, we may put excessive stress on our body and actually increase our risk of infection.⁠
⁠
Beta glucan, a special type of fiber found in baker’s, nutritional, and brewer’s yeasts, may prevent this immune decline in marathon runners. Indeed, a study found that we can better maintain our level of circulating white blood cells after exhaustive exercise by consuming beta glucan.⁠
⁠
Watch the video “Preserving Immune Function in Athletes with Nutritional Yeast” at https://bit.ly/3tPt9zI to learn more.⁠
⁠
⁠

node.text:
Stone Fruit Bowls from the How Not to Diet Cookbook, a delicious summer dessert recipe. 

A drupe, more commonly known as stone fruit, is so named because it contains a stone (or a pit) inside. Many popular stone fruits, such as cherries, plums, peaches, nectarines, mangoes, and dates are in season in late summer. 

INGREDIENTS:
3 tablespoons ground chia seeds
1 1/2 cups fresh or thawed frozen diced mango
1 teaspoon fresh lemon juice
2 pitted soft dates, soaked for 10 minutes in hot water and then drained
3 ripe apricots, pitted and quartered
3 ripe plums, pitted and cut into 1-inch pieces
2 ripe peaches or nectarines, pitted and cut into 1-inch pieces
2 cups pitted cherries

METHOD:
In a small bowl, combine the chia seeds and 1/4 cup water and mix well. Set aside for 10 minutes to thicken.

In a food processor or a blender, combine the mango, lemon juice, dates, and the chia mixture and process until smooth. Divide equally among four small glass dessert bowls. Cover and refrigerate until firm (about 4 hours).

Combine the apricots, plums, peaches, and cherries in a large bowl. Toss gently to combine.

To serve, spoon the fruit evenly over the chilled mango mixture. Serve immediately.

Serves 4

node.text:
Here's a delicious Mango Blueberry Smoothie to try this week! The recipe features amla, also known as Indian gooseberry, it is one of the most antioxidant-rich foods on Earth. Learn more about amla here: nutritionfacts.org/topics/amla

INGREDIENTS:
1 cup unsweetened soymilk
½ cup frozen blueberries
½ cup frozen mango
½ cup frozen banana slices
1 Tbsp ground flaxseed
½ cup fresh mint leaves
1 teaspoon amla powder

METHOD:
Add all the ingredients to a blender and blend until smooth. Enjoy!

node.text:
Fewer than 2 percent of Americans achieve even the recommended minimum intake of potassium, due primarily to inadequate plant food intake. We need 4,700 mg of potassium a day. Watch the video “98 Percent of American Diets Potassium-Deficient” at https://bit.ly/2HeGYTZ to learn more.⁠
⁠
Greens are win-win—rich in nitrates and a good source of potassium. Nitrates from green leafy veggies are converted to nitric oxide in the body, and potassium increases nitric-oxide release. Including foods high in nitrates and potassium can help lower blood pressure and improve arterial function. Learn more from the video “Lowering Our Sodium-to-Potassium Ratio to Reduce Stroke Risk” at https://bit.ly/2sR8mfP⁠
⁠
⁠

node.text:
Here is a refreshing Lemon-Ginger Cooler from the How Not to Die Cookbook to make this week! 

INGREDIENTS:
1 (2-inch) piece fresh ginger sliced
2 tablespoons lemon juice
1 (4-inch) piece cinnamon stick (optional)
Date Syrup, to taste (recipe below)
mint, for serving (optional)

METHOD:
1) Combine 4 cups of water with the ginger in a large saucepan and bring to a boil.
2) Remove from the heat. Add the lemon and cinnamon stick (if using) and set aside for 30 minutes
3) Sweeten to taste with Date Syrup (if using). Refrigerate until chilled. Serve in a tall glass over ice. Add mint if you're in the mood. Makes enough for about 2 people.

Date Syrup Recipe:
1 cup pitted dates
1 cup boiling water
1 teaspoon lemon juice 

METHOD:
Combine the dates and hot water in a heatproof bowl and set aside for 1 hour to soften the dates. Transfer the dates and water to a high-speed blender. Add the lemon and blend until smooth. Transfer to a glass jar or other airtight container with a tight-fitting lid. Store the syrup in the refrigerator for up to 2 to 3 weeks

Recipe for Lemon-Ginger Cooler is also here:
http://bit.ly/LemonGingerCooler

Recipe for homemade Date Syrup is here: http://bit.ly/HNTDdatesyrup

node.text:
If you have Dr. Greger's first recipe collection, The How Not to Die Cookbook, you'll recognize the one-and-only Robin Robertson. She's joined Dr. Greger once again to develop more than a hundred absolutely delicious whole food, plant-based recipes inspired by cuisines around the world for The How Not to Diet Cookbook. Not only is every single recipe included in this new collection health-promoting, but every ingredient of every recipe is healthful. All recipes are composed of 100% Green-Light ingredients.⁠
⁠
Here's a tiny sample of what's in the new cookbook:⁠
Red Bean and Butternut Caldo Verde⁠
Thai Green Papaya Salad⁠
Zucchini Linguini with Mushroom-Lentil Bolognese⁠
Jicama Nachos⁠
Black Forest Chia Pudding⁠
⁠
Learn more about The How Not to Diet Cookbook here: http://bit.ly/HowNotToDietCookbook⁠
*100% of the proceeds Dr. Greger receives from all his books are donated to charity.⁠
⁠
*To access the URL, click the link in our bio and then select this image. ⁠
⁠
#HowNotToDiet #HowNotToDietcookbook #HowNotToDie #HowNotToDieCookbook #NutritionFactsOrg #DailyDozen #DailyDozenChallenge #dailydozendigest #wfpb #plantbasedrecipes #wfpbrecipes #eatmoreplants #NutritionFacts #weightlossjourney #plantbasedmeals #wfpbweightloss #plantbasednutrition #plantbasedlifestyle #plantbasedcooking #beansandgreens

Fiber is what our good gut bacteria thrive on, their fuel source. When we eat whole plant foods, like fruits, vegetables, beans, and whole grains, we are telling our gut flora to be fruitful and multiply. http://bit.ly/2G8y1fm

May be an image of text that says 'During the fiber fermentation process, our gut flora produce short-chain fatty acids (SCFA), which are an important source of energy for the cells lining our colon. So, we feed our flora with fiber, and they turn around and feed us right back. These SCFA help suppress inflammation and cancer. You can learn more about SCFA here: https://bit.ly/3u9001w.
